data.title: The Adventures of Prince Achmed (1926)
data.meta_description: Based on stories from "The Arabian Nights". A wicked sorcerer tricks Prince Achmed into riding a magical flying horse. The heroic prince is able to subdue the magical horse, which he uses to fly off to many adventures. While travelling, he falls in love with the beautiful Princess Peri Banu, and must defeat an army of demons to win her heart. The film is animated using the silhouette technique.
data.text:
"Prince Achmed was young and brave and not afraid of any adventure."

Though clarity and pace occasionally waver, even for the admittedly brief runtime, Lotte Reiniger's skill does not. The Adventures of Prince Achmed is pure cinematic magic, a journey where one feels the careful attention and absolute delight of every painstaking second birthed from the filmmaker's inventive artistic style. Dubbed "silhouette animation" for the technique's use of numerous cutouts, as well as other tricks of the trade involved in the three-year production beginning in 1923, Reiniger's remarkable work manages to effortlessly impress nearly a century later. The compositions are sublime, the ingenuity and splendor of each unquestionable. One struggles to even fathom the patience and vision required from one…

This animated fairytale written and directed by German filmmaker Lotte Reiniger has the prestigious distinction of being the oldest animated feature film. However, it's amply more than just a crucial component of film history, as the feature, which may on initial look seem rather rudimentary, is absorbingly stunning and formulates an exceptionally high level of admiration.

It promotes a technique of silhouette animation which recalls the ancient storytelling technique of shadow puppetry and captions an imaginative usage of shapes and settings, and it's extraordinary how much expression Reiniger achieves with virtually nothing other than exact hand movements from the silhouettes. A great deal of thought has occurred in the editing, and the results are nothing beneath creative and inventive; tinting…
